title: The Craziest Anti-Gay Laws in America
description:
Although the United States has made huge progress on gay
  rights over the last few years, many individual states retain odd,
  antiquated, or downright vicious anti-gay laws.

questions.feedback:
John and Abigail Adams had a prolific correspondence and
      next-level pen names. He called her Diana after the Roman goddess of
      the moon and adopted the name Lysander after the hero of Sparta.
      When not playing their classical counterparts, Abigail often called
      John “My Dearest Friend.”

Abraham and Mary Todd Lincoln were quite formal with each
      other, and started calling each other Father and Mother after their
      children were born.

questions.explainer:
The correct answer is Franky and Janie. All of the Pierce
      children died young, and poor Jane Pierce spent much of her term as
      first lady mourning in solitude.

questions.feedback:
Rutherford and Lucy Hayes were Ruddy and Lu. Can you imagine
      being called Rutherford all the time?

James and Lucretia Garfield went by Jim and Crete. How we wish
      President Garfield answered to “Garf.”

The correct answer is Chet and Nell. President Arthur’s middle
      name was Alan.

The correct answer is Uncle Steve and Frank. Frank Cleveland
      married then-President Grover Cleveland in 1886, when she was 21 and he
      was 49. He had known her since she was a little girl and eventually
      started called him Grover (once the Uncle thing got too weird).

Sonny and Flossie is the correct answer, although President
      Harding often called Florence “Duchess.” And Jerry? Well, that’s his
      penis’ name, of course!

The correct answer is Thee and Wifie. Alice, Roosevelt’s first
      wife, was never first lady, but Roosevelt was fully devoted to her. He
      actually never liked “Teddy” although his family called him “Teedie”
      for quite some time.

Unfortunately, the correct Taft nicknames are the most boring
      option. William and Helen called each other Will and Nellie.

Nancy did often call Reagan “Ronnie”, but the mutual
      pairing here is Poppa and Mommie, used frequently within their
      correspondence. In one Valentine’s Day missive from 1960, Mommie even
      became “Mommie-Poo.”

George H.W. Bush and Barbara Pierce met in high school,
      when they were known as Poppy and Barbi. Incidentally, Babs is a nickname
      that FDR often used for Eleanor.
